content: If this is an IMAP account, Thunderbird saves the draft periodically. If the time to write the message is longer than the time to save a draft, thunderbird saves it again. If you take longer time to write the message, thunderbird continues periodically to save more drafts. when the message is finally sent, thunderbird issues the command to delete the draft, but can cause the other drafts to remain. You have to manually delete those. OR, you can set the drafts folder to be local, in which case this situation never materializes.
creator: davidsk

content:
1. Sent

The settings you have set up are correct for a Pop account. You should not be needing to alter anything.

Possible reasons for a setting not being recognised. You have a program on your computer that cleans up temp files, session files, cache etc. Products such as CCleaner or WiseCleaner or even some Anti-Virus products can 'clean up' files. It means something could be messing about in places where they should not be allowed and it can cause a nuisance. If you have installed such a program then you need to access it and make an exception to not have access to your Thunderbird profile. That includes any Anti-Virus. Anti-Virus can cause problems because if allowed to scan and auto fix files, they could cause major data loss. AV's have no concept that one simple text file may contain more than one email. So a fix may mean delete the contents of file. If you have had Thunderbird for a while then it's likely the Thunderbird folder that needs being make exempt from scanning is here:

  • C:Users/username/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird


The 'Sent' folder does not display items because the index file does not match the real contents in the mbox file.

  • Right click on 'Sent' folder and select 'Properties'
  • Click on 'Repair Folder'
  • click on 'OK'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Do you have any VPN running? Many servers do not like a VPN as it hides your IP address. Many Anti-Virus products now offer a VPN and in some cases I've discovered they were auto enabled. Please double check to see if a VPN was enabled - switch it off. If you discover a VPN then check for a Kill Switch - some VPN if connection is lost will invoke a Kill Switch which stops internet connection.

re :add my Spectrum email back in Thunderbird, I presume the lost Thunderbird meant you had to reinstall Thunderbird or when you started Thunderbird it had lost knowing how to access the mail account acting ike it was using a new profile.

Did you also remove all the previously saved passwords? If no then please check now and remove them if they still exist.

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll to Passwords section
  • click on 'Saved Passwords'

Do you have any lines where the 'username' = the email address of account you are trying to add back into Thunderbird ? Normally, each account would have two lines one for incoming and one for outoing. Select each relevant line and click on 'Remove'. Then Exit Thunderbird to force background processes to properly update file. Upon restart - try to create account.

Are you talking about a 'spectrum' email address or another that uses the spectrum server? Are you using a password that spectrum says is 'secure' ? Maybe Spectrum is being awkward because it wants you to set up a new password that they deem as more secure. eg: uses 12 chars, uses upper and lower case with numerals.

content:
There is a possibility, but it's tedious. If you have not compacted the folders, try this:

  1. click help>troubleshootinginformation
  2. scroll to 'profile folders' and click 'open folder'
  3. exit thunderbird
  4. you are now in the profile. If the messages were in an IMAP account (that's my guess), click the imapmail folder and then the account folder. you should see the folder with the missing messages, such as INBOX, INBOX.msf. Ignore the msf files.
  5. Open the file "Inbox" with Notepad or a similar text editor. ("INBOX" has no suffix; do not open "INBOX.msf.") Locate your deleted email by searching the document.
  6. Locate the line before your email text that reads "X-Mozilla-Status: 000X" (where 'X' is any character other than 0). Change the number to four zeros (″0000"). Repeat for all other messages. Save the document and exit Notepad
  7. Now, COPY the file to the Mail\Local Folders folder in the profile
  8. restart thunderbird and the messages should appear.

content:
I find that such hanging is rare, which suggest to me that there's some local factor that makes it worse for you. Some things you might look into...

- Could be one of your add-ons is misbehaving. Try disabling them or running Thunderbird in Troubleshooting Mode to see if the problem goes away.

- Disable Hardware Acceleration in Thunderbird - it can sometimes contribute to display or performance anomalies.

- Try excluding your Thunderbird profile from your antivirus.

But to address your original question, You can End Task from Windows Task Manager. Right-click on an empty spot on the Toolbar to find it. There may be multiple Thunderbird processes.

content:
How about this, found online:

On Windows 11, you can force-close unresponsive apps directly from the Taskbar using the End task option. However, this feature is disabled by default and must be turned on manually. To enable the “End Task” option from the Advanced page, follow these steps:

- Open Settings on Windows 11.

- Click on System.

- Click the Advanced page.

- Turn on the “End Task” toggle switch under the “Taskbar settings.

content:
If Firefox can't connect to their web mail site, that seems like a pretty clear indication that either they are having a problem or they have changed their server addresses. Does your email provider have a help/support page where you can check to see if the web mail site is up?

There are a few web site that can check to see if another site or domain is down. Google the phrase "is that web site down" and you'll find a few. The one I often use is called, "Is It Down Right Now."

Many ISPs that had provided email services are now subcontracting those services to third-party hosts. My ISP, Xfinity/Comcast, has announced that their email will be moving to Yahoo, though it hasn't happened yet. I don't find that these companies are necessarily very good at keeping their customers informed. I wonder if you may be caught up in the crossfire of one of these transitions?

content:
I have no idea why your filters do not work. But I like everyone else on this forum know exactly what you tell us about your issue and so far all you have said is something is not working. What I have not idea, or what it is you are trying to achieve from that filter.

Perhaps if you were to share exactly what they were someone might stand a chance of understanding why they do not work for you. My experience is that most folk that have troubles with filters are not applying them correctly and the logic of the filter is the problem.

SO starting with the information to supply. 1. What account is selected in the filter dialog when you filter are listed? It is not uncommon for filter to be created in the wrong account. 2. What exactly is the criteria you are filtering on as shown in the filter dialog? 3. What exactly is the criteria being used as an action from the filter? It is not uncommon for folk to have two filters, the first executed filter moves the message somewhere else and they then complain that the next filter does not work correctly on the message that is no longer in the folder to be filtered.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Good afternoon! Emails to smtp.gmail.com have stopped sending. I can receive emails without any problems, but when sending I get an error

Message sending error. The message could not be sent because a connection to the outgoing mail server (SMTP) "smtp.gmail.com" could not be established. The server may be unavailable or refusing SMTP connections. Make sure you have entered the correct outgoing mail server (SMTP) settings and try again.

We have tried outgoing server settings with starttls/587/oauth2 and ssltls/465/oauth2 - the error is the same. The problem appeared only today; everything was working fine before. Emails send without any issues from the browser. On another PC with Thunderbird and this email, the situation is the same. Emails from other domains send without any problems.

----

I use SSLTLS, 465, Oauth2 with no problems. You might check settings>privacy&security to ensure that thunderbird accepts cookies. Otherwise, I have no idea what the problem might be.
creator: davidsk

creator: wsmwk

content:
Yes, if you are familiar with Windows File Explorer and your profile, it's a simple copy/paste item. In the old profile, its name is abook.sqlite and the collected addressbook is history.sqlite. Just copy and paste into the new profile.

If you're unsure the disc location of the active profile, do this first:

  1. click help>troubleshootinginformation
  2. scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  3. EXIT thunderbird here
  4. you are now in the profile. Paste those two files here.

If the version of thunderbird on old PC was OLDER than version 78, post back for different instructions.
creator: davidsk

content:
Then turn off threading! the instructions have been in the support documents for a number of years now. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/message-threading-thunderbird#

I will include a picture of the settings that replace the Changing default threading mode from that article so you will know them when you find them
